questions.text: A 57-year-old nulliparous woman comes to the physician 2 weeks after noticing a lump in her right breast. Her last mammogram was performed 4 years ago and showed no abnormalities. Menopause began 2 years ago, during which time the patient was prescribed hormone replacement therapy for severe hot flashes and vaginal dryness. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination of the right breast shows a firm, nontender mass close to the nipple. There are no changes in the skin or nipple, and there is no palpable axillary adenopathy. The abdomen is soft and nontender; there is no organomegaly. Mammography shows a suspicious 2-cm mass adjacent to the nipple. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Fine needle aspiration (FNA) cytology cannot provide information about the tissue architecture or receptor status. In patients with a palpable breast lump and suspicious findings on imaging, FNA has been superseded by a more sensitive and more specific modality. The primary role of FNA nowadays is the evaluation of nonsuspicious, cystic lesions in women younger than 30 years of age.

B) INCORRECT:

Excisional biopsy (e.g., via lumpectomy) is an invasive procedure and is therefore not the most appropriate next step in diagnosing breast cancer. It may, however, be used for diagnosis in this patient if the appropriate next step is inconclusive but imaging shows a suspicious lesion or if the appropriate next step cannot be performed (e.g., lack of facilities or expertise for ultrasound-guided procedures).

C) INCORRECT:

In patients with suspected breast cancer, a bone scan is indicated in patients with localized bone pain and/or increased ALP and in all patients with stage III breast cancer or higher. In this patient, whose lymph nodes do not show signs of disease and who does not have bone pain, it would be inappropriate to perform a bone scan before performing tissue diagnosis and axillary staging.

D) INCORRECT:

CA15-3, which is a tumor marker in patients with breast cancer, is used for the follow-up of patients who have already received treatment and not for the diagnosis of breast cancer.

E) INCORRECT:

A mastectomy would be indicated if histological examination of the tissue specimen obtained by the appropriate next step suggested breast cancer, and breast-conserving therapy was not indicated (e.g., tumor > 5 cm, a mass with microcalcifications, or a widespread disease that cannot be removed via single incision), or if the patient wished to undergo mastectomy. In a patient with a palpable breast lump, a mastectomy should not be performed without confirmation of breast cancer by tissue diagnosis.

F) CORRECT:

A core needle biopsy is the most appropriate next step in the management of a patient with a palpable breast lump and imaging findings suggestive of breast cancer. This test is used to confirm the diagnosis, evaluate the extent of the tumor, and describe the histology of the tumor and its receptor profile.
Image Description:

DBT: digital breast tomosynthesis
questions.hint: This patient has suspicious findings on mammography and multiple risk factors for breast cancer, including nulliparity, late menopause, and hormone replacement therapy.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 2, comes to the physician for the evaluation of a palpable mass in her right breast that she first noticed 1 week ago. She has no associated pain. She has never had a mammogram. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus treated with metformin. She has no family history of breast cancer. She has smoked half a pack of cigarettes daily for 15 years. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 78/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 125/75 mm Hg. Examination shows a firm, nonpainful, nonmobile mass in the right upper quadrant of the breast. There is no nipple discharge. Examination of the skin and lymph nodes shows no abnormalities. No masses are palpated in the left breast. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

MRI scan of the breast is indicated for the workup of a suspicious breast lump when routine imaging tests are inconclusive or as a screening tool when the patient has an increased risk for breast cancer (e.g., a BRCA mutation carrier). However, none of these conditions apply.

B) CORRECT:

Mammography is the recommended imaging modality for the evaluation of a palpable breast mass in women ≥ 30 years of age. Along with clinical assessment, it is the initial step in breast cancer diagnosis and helps in deciding whether a biopsy is further required.

Ultrasonography is the initial imaging modality of choice in women < 30 years of age.
Image Description:

DBT: digital breast tomosynthesis

C) INCORRECT:

Fine-needle aspiration is the recommended diagnostic modality for evaluating a nonsuspicious breast mass (e.g., soft movable mass), but is performed after imaging. This patient also already has signs concerning for malignancy.

D) INCORRECT:

Although core needle biopsy is part of the workup of breast lumps when there is suspicion of malignancy, it is performed after imaging.

E) INCORRECT:

BRCA gene testing is recommended for evaluating breast cancer in patients with a family history of breast, ovarian, tubal, or peritoneal cancer, or in some patients after breast cancer is diagnosed (e.g., triple-negative or bilateral breast cancer). However, none of these conditions apply.

F) INCORRECT:

A monthly self-breast exam is not a recommended strategy for this patient since she has a breast lump concerning for breast cancer, which requires further workup.

G) INCORRECT:

Ultrasonography is the recommended initial imaging test for a self-palpated breast lump in women younger than 30 years of age because it offers higher sensitivity than a mammogram. Young women have higher density breast tissue, which makes the detection of breast abnormalities in a mammogram more difficult.
questions.hint: This patient's nontender, firm, nonmobile breast mass should raise concern for breast cancer.

questions.text: A 27-year-old nulliparous woman comes to the office because of a lump in her left breast that she first noticed 2 weeks ago. Her medical history is unremarkable. Her last menstrual period was 3 weeks ago. Her aunt was diagnosed with ovarian cancer at the age of 55 years. The patient has smoked one-half pack of cigarettes daily for 9 years and drinks one to two alcoholic beverages weekly. She is 170 cm (5 ft 7 in) tall and weighs 63 kg (139 lb); BMI is 22 kg/m2. Her temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 76/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 115/65 mm Hg. Palpation of the left breast discloses a firm, rigid, nontender mass in the upper outer quadrant; the overlying skin shows no abnormalities. There is no nipple discharge. Examination of the right breast shows no abnormalities and axillary lymph nodes are not palpable. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

BRCA gene testing is recommended for evaluating breast cancer in patients with a family history of breast, ovarian, tubal, or peritoneal cancer, or in some patients after breast cancer (e.g., triple-negative or bilateral breast cancer) is diagnosed. Although this patient has a family history of ovarian cancer, testing is only indicated after the diagnosis is made and if a first-degree relative is affected.

B) CORRECT:

Breast ultrasound is the most appropriate next step when evaluating a palpable breast mass in women < 30 years of age. Premenopausal women < 30 years of age often have dense breast tissue, which decreases the diagnostic accuracy of mammography in these individuals. Furthermore, ultrasound imaging does not expose the patient to ionizing radiation, unlike mammography. Breast ultrasonography helps distinguish solid lesions from benign cysts, as well as evaluate axillary, supraclavicular, and infraclavicular lymph nodes. If imaging reveals signs of malignancy (e.g., mass irregularity, heterogenicity, spiculated margin), mammography, in addition to ultrasound, can be performed and a biopsy of the lesion is indicated.

For women between 30 and 39 years of age, both mammography and ultrasound can be used; mammography is the recommended imaging modality in women ≥ 40 years of age.
Image Description:

DBT: digital breast tomosynthesis

C) INCORRECT:

Reassurance and follow-up are indicated in the case of a benign breast lesion, such as fibroadenoma, which is the most common breast tumor in women < 35 years of age. Benign breast lesions are typically soft, well-defined, and mobile, unlike this patient's firm, rigid, and nontender mass. This approach is appropriate only after the diagnosis is established.

D) INCORRECT:

Core needle biopsy (CNB) is used to assess a palpable breast mass with findings that suggest malignancy (e.g., firm, rigid, nontender mass). Because CNB has high sensitivity and specificity, it is used to evaluate the extent of the tumor, as well as its histology and receptor profile. Although CNB is part of the workup of breast lumps, it is performed after imaging.

E) INCORRECT:

Mammography is used for the evaluation of palpable breast masses in women ≥ 40 years of age. This screening modality is also recommended for breast cancer screening in this age group (i.e., ≥ 40 years) because it can detect the majority of malignancies and lesions ∼ 2 years before they are clinically evident. However, this imaging modality is less sensitive in younger patients with high breast density.
Image Description:

Mammography (right breast; craniocaudal view)

A mass (circled) with suspicious features, including high density and indistinct margins, is visible in the posterior third of the breast.
questions.hint: A palpable breast mass requires further assessment regardless of the clinical features of the mass and the patient's age.

questions.text:
Patient Information
Age: 41 years
Gender: F, self-identified
Race/Ethnicity: unspecified
Site of Care: clinic
History
Reason for Visit/Chief Concern: routine breast cancer screening
History of Present Illness:

occasional mild breast tenderness that self-resolves
menarche at 12 years of age, regular menstrual cycles
last menstrual period began 3 days ago

gravida 1, para 0, pregnancy was 2 years ago
no history of breast, uterine, ovarian, or colorectal cancers

Past Medical History:
unremarkable
Medications:
oral contraceptive pill
Vaccinations:
up-to-date
Allergies:
no known drug allergies
Family History:
no family history of breast cancer
Psychosocial History:

smokes one pack of cigarettes per week
does not drink alcohol or use any other substances

Physical Examination


Temp
Pulse
Resp
BP
O2 Sat
Ht
Wt
BMI


37.2°C(99.0°F)
82/min
16/min
120/70 mm Hg
-
165 cm(5 ft 5 in)
68 kg(150 lb)
25 kg/m2




Appearance: appears well; no acute distress
HEENT: normal conjunctivae and oropharynx
Neck: no cervical lymphadenopathy
Pulmonary: clear lung fields
Cardiac: regular rhythm; no murmurs
Chest: normal, symmetrical breasts with no masses on palpation; no nipple discharge or overlying skin changes; no axillary lymphadenopathy
Pelvic: mild vulvovaginal atrophy; no cervical tenderness; uterus normal in size and shape; no adnexal masses or tenderness 

Diagnostic Studies
mammography: extremely dense breast tissue throughout; one group of clustered, amorphous microcalcifications in the upper outer quadrant of the right breast

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Intraductal papilloma mainly affects individuals between 30 and 50 years of age and mammography findings may include calcifications, but the condition typically manifests with a palpable, retroareolar mass that is well-defined and has regular borders on imaging.

B) CORRECT:

Ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) is often detected early on mammography screening as grouped, amorphous microcalcifications. In contrast, lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS) does not typically manifest with calcifications and is difficult to detect on standard breast imaging. Although DCIS and LCIS are technically considered nonmalignant because they do not cross the basement membrane, both increase the risk of invasive breast cancer. Mammography findings that raise suspicion for malignancy include grouped microcalcifications, an irregularly shaped mass with indistinct borders and spiculated margins, and a high breast density. See “Features of breast mass on mammography” table.
Image Description:

Mammography (right breast; mediolateral oblique view)

A high-density mass (green overlay) with an indistinct margin and containing microcalcifications (examples indicated by red overlay) projects in the upper breast.

The features of this lesion are highly suspicious for malignancy.

C) INCORRECT:

Sclerosing adenosis is a common benign lesion of the breast and may manifest with cyclic mastalgia and calcifications on mammography, but the calcifications are typically diffuse rather than clustered.

D) INCORRECT:

Mondor disease of the breast may manifest with noncyclical mastalgia, but the typical manifestation is the sudden onset of a tender, cord-like induration, which corresponds to a superficial tubular structure that has a beaded appearance on mammography.

E) INCORRECT:

Fat necrosis of the breast can resemble malignancy and manifest with grouped calcifications on mammography. However, the calcifications typically have a coarse rim or eggshell appearance, and the findings are frequently associated with a spiculated mass or fluid-filled oil cyst. Moreover, fat necrosis often involves skin changes (e.g., reaction, erythema, and ecchymosis) and a history of trauma, surgery, or radiation of the breast.
questions.hint: Risk factors associated with this condition include nulliparity, obesity, early menarche, and late menopause.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old gravida 5, para 4 woman presents at 33 weeks' gestation with a painless breast mass. She breastfed her last child until she found out she was 12 weeks pregnant. She has no personal or family history of breast cancer. She has a 15-pack-year history of cigarette smoking but has not smoked during her pregnancies.
On examination, she has a firm, mobile, 2-cm mass in the right breast at the 6 o’clock position. There are no overlying skin changes and no axillary lymphadenopathy.
What is the most appropriate initial step in evaluation for this patient?

choices.text: Deferral of investigation until the patient is postpartum

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

If the lesion is solid or has other concerning characteristics on ultrasound, there are various options for next steps. Mammography is typically preferred over MRI in this setting, and core biopsy may eventually be necessary. With proper shielding, mammography can be done safely without jeopardizing the fetus, but ultrasound is still usually preferred as the first-line imaging modality.

B) INCORRECT:

If the lesion is solid or has other concerning characteristics on ultrasound, there are various options for next steps. Mammography is typically preferred over MRI in this setting, and core biopsy may eventually be necessary.

C) INCORRECT:

If the lesion is solid or has other concerning characteristics on ultrasound, there are various options for next steps. Mammography is typically preferred over MRI in this setting, and core biopsy may eventually be necessary.

D) CORRECT:

Malignant breast masses tend to be hard, immobile, and fixed, with indiscrete margins, and overlying skin changes may be present. In contrast, benign breast masses are often smooth and mobile, with discrete margins, and do not cause skin changes. Physical examination is not sufficiently sensitive to distinguish between malignant and benign breast masses, so imaging is warranted for all women with a detectable mass.

Ultrasound of the breast is typically performed first for breast masses in women who are pregnant or under age 30, given the desire to minimize radiation exposure in these populations. With proper shielding, mammography can be done safely without jeopardizing the fetus, but ultrasound is still usually preferred as the first-line imaging modality.

If the lesion is solid or has other concerning characteristics on ultrasound, there are various options for next steps. Mammography is typically preferred over MRI in this setting, and core biopsy may eventually be necessary.

Key learning point: The most appropriate initial evaluation for a pregnant woman with a breast mass is ultrasound of the breast.

E) INCORRECT:

Deferring further investigation until the postpartum period is not appropriate in a pregnant woman with a breast mass, given the risk of delaying diagnosis of possible pregnancy-associated breast cancer. In general, pregnancy is not a reason to delay workup of concerning medical findings.

She has smoked half a pack of cigarettes daily for 15 years. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 78/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 125/75 mm Hg. No masses are palpated in the left breast. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management?

A) INCORRECT:

C) INCORRECT:

D) INCORRECT:

E) INCORRECT:

Although this patient has a family history of ovarian cancer, testing is only indicated after the diagnosis is made and if a first-degree relative is affected.

Breast ultrasound is the most appropriate next step when evaluating a palpable breast mass in women < 30 years of age. For women between 30 and 39 years of age, both mammography and ultrasound can be used; mammography is the recommended imaging modality in women ≥ 40 years of age.

Image Description:

DBT: digital breast tomosynthesis

C) INCORRECT:

Reassurance and follow-up are indicated in the case of a benign breast lesion, such as fibroadenoma, which is the most common breast tumor in women < 35 years of age. Although CNB is part of the workup of breast lumps, it is performed after imaging.

Image Description:

Mammography (right breast; craniocaudal view)

A mass (circled) with suspicious features, including high density and indistinct margins, is visible in the posterior third of the breast.

questions.text: A 57-year-old nulliparous woman comes to the office 2 weeks after noticing a lump in her right breast. Her last mammogram was performed 4 years ago and showed no abnormalities. Menopause began 5 years ago, during which time the patient was prescribed hormone replacement therapy for severe hot flashes and vaginal dryness. Examination of the right breast shows a firm, nontender mass close to the nipple. There are no changes in the skin or nipple, and there is no palpable axillary adenopathy. The abdomen is soft and nontender; there is no organomegaly. Mammography shows a noncircumscribed 2-cm mass adjacent to the nipple. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Fine needle aspiration (FNA) cytology cannot provide information about the tissue architecture or receptor status. In patients with a palpable breast lump and suspicious findings on imaging, FNA has been superseded by a more sensitive and more specific modality. The primary role of FNA nowadays is the evaluation of nonsuspicious, cystic lesions in women younger than 30 years of age.

B) INCORRECT:

Excisional biopsy (e.g., via lumpectomy) is an invasive procedure and is therefore not the most appropriate next step in diagnosing breast cancer. It may, however, be used for diagnosis in this patient if the appropriate next step is inconclusive but imaging shows a suspicious lesion or if the appropriate next step cannot be performed (e.g., lack of facilities or expertise for ultrasound-guided procedures).

C) INCORRECT:

CA15-3, which is a tumor marker in patients with breast cancer, is used for the follow-up of patients who have already received treatment and not for the diagnosis of breast cancer.

D) INCORRECT:

Ultrasonography is indicated for all patients with a palpable breast mass and inconclusive mammography. This patient presents with a detectable breast mass on mammography, which requires a different management.

E) CORRECT:

A core needle biopsy is the most appropriate next step in the management of a patient with a palpable breast lump and imaging findings suggestive of breast cancer. This test is used to confirm the diagnosis, evaluate the extent of the tumor, and describe the histology of the tumor and its receptor profile.
Image Description:

DBT: digital breast tomosynthesis
questions.hint: This patient has suspicious findings on mammography and multiple risk factors for breast cancer, including nulliparity, late menopause, and hormone replacement therapy.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a two-month history of a left breast lump noticed during self-examination. She has no known family history of breast or ovarian cancer. Physical examination confirms a 2-cm, well-circumscribed, mobile, non-tender mass in the upper outer quadrant, with no skin changes or axillary lymphadenopathy.
Which of the following is the most appropriate initial imaging study for further evaluation?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Breast MRI is reserved for high-risk patients or detailed preoperative planning in confirmed malignancies. It is highly sensitive but less specific, leading to potential false positives and unnecessary procedures. In young women with likely benign masses, ultrasound is more appropriate for initial evaluation.

B) CORRECT:

Breast ultrasound is preferred for evaluating breast masses in young women due to dense breast tissue, which limits mammography's sensitivity. Ultrasound effectively differentiates between cystic and solid masses, aiding in the assessment of benign versus malignant lesions. It provides detailed information on lesion margins and internal characteristics without ionizing radiation, making it suitable for women under 30. Ultrasound can also guide further diagnostic procedures, such as biopsies, if needed.

Key learning point: In women under 40 with breast symptoms, ultrasound is the preferred initial imaging modality due to its effectiveness in evaluating dense breast tissue.
Image Description:

DBT: digital breast tomosynthesis

C) INCORRECT:

Diagnostic mammography is less effective in young women due to dense breast tissue, which reduces its sensitivity and specificity. Additionally, mammography involves ionizing radiation, which is generally avoided in younger patients when alternatives like ultrasound are available. Ultrasound is more effective for evaluating palpable breast masses in this age group.

D) INCORRECT:

Fine needle aspiration (FNA) is used for cytologic evaluation of breast lesions but does not provide structural information. Initial imaging, such as ultrasound, is crucial for assessing lesion characteristics and guiding decisions on tissue sampling. FNA is not suitable as the initial step in evaluating a palpable breast mass.

questions.text:
A 49-year-old woman undergoes routine screening mammography in the Outpatient Clinic. She has no significant family history of breast cancer but is anxious because a distant relative was recently diagnosed with breast cancer. She reports no breast pain or palpable lump. Physical examination is normal, without axillary lymphadenopathy (see report).
Mammography: New, 0.8-cm well-circumscribed, round mass in the upper outer quadrant of the right breast; no associated calcifications or architectural distortion; BI-RADS category 3, probably benign
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Immediate surgical excision for definitive diagnosis
Immediate core needle biopsy under ultrasound guidance
Repeat routine annual screening with no earlier imaging
Follow-up mammogram in 6 months to assess for stability

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Immediate surgical excision is not warranted for BI-RADS category 3 lesions, which are probably benign. The lesion is small, well-circumscribed, and lacks suspicious features. Surgical excision is reserved for lesions with definitive signs of malignancy or those that change on follow-up imaging. This approach would unnecessarily expose the patient to surgical risks.

B) INCORRECT:

A core needle biopsy is not indicated for a BI-RADS 3 lesion, which is probably benign. The lesion is well-circumscribed and lacks suspicious features. Biopsy is reserved for lesions with irregular margins or calcifications. Immediate biopsy introduces unnecessary procedural risks without sufficient justification.

C) INCORRECT:

A new BI-RADS 3 lesion requires short-term follow-up imaging rather than waiting for the next annual screening. The absence of previous imaging demonstrating stability necessitates earlier re-evaluation to confirm the lesion remains unchanged, ensuring any subtle changes are detected promptly.

D) CORRECT:

BI-RADS category 3 lesions are considered probably benign, with less than a 2% chance of malignancy. The lesion in question is 0.8 cm, well-circumscribed, and lacks suspicious features such as irregular margins or calcifications. Standard management involves a follow-up mammogram in 6 months to monitor for changes, balancing the low risk of cancer with the need for timely diagnosis. This approach avoids unnecessary invasive procedures while ensuring any changes are promptly identified.

Key learning point: BI-RADS III findings are probably benign, and the appropriate management is short interval follow-up imaging to monitor for any changes.

questions.text:
A 29-year-old woman who is 18 weeks pregnant presents to the clinic with a two-week history of a 1.5-cm lump in her left breast. She notices mild tenderness over the area but no skin changes. Her older sister was diagnosed with breast cancer at age 34. Physical examination reveals a well-defined subareolar mass without axillary lymphadenopathy. She is anxious about malignancy.
What is the most appropriate initial imaging study?

choices.text: MRI of both breasts with contrast

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

In pregnant patients with a palpable breast mass, bilateral breast ultrasound is the preferred initial imaging modality due to its safety and diagnostic efficacy. Ultrasound uses sound waves, avoiding ionizing radiation, which is crucial for fetal safety. It effectively differentiates between cystic and solid masses, aiding in management decisions. During pregnancy, breast tissue is denser, making ultrasound more informative than mammography. Additionally, ultrasound can guide biopsies if needed, providing both diagnostic and procedural utility.

Key learning point: In pregnant women with a breast mass, bilateral breast ultrasound is the preferred initial imaging modality to evaluate the mass safely and effectively.

B) INCORRECT:

Breast MRI with contrast is highly sensitive but not ideal initially in pregnancy due to concerns about gadolinium crossing the placenta. Hormonal changes during pregnancy can also complicate MRI interpretation. Ultrasound is safer and more appropriate for initial evaluation.

C) INCORRECT:

PET/CT involves significant ionizing radiation, posing risks to the fetus. It is used for staging or assessing metastatic disease, not for initial evaluation of a localized breast mass in pregnancy. Ultrasound is safer and more appropriate for initial assessment.

D) INCORRECT:

Mammography with abdominal shielding minimizes fetal radiation exposure but is less informative in younger women due to dense breast tissue. Ultrasound is preferred initially in pregnancy for its ability to differentiate between solid and cystic lesions without ionizing radiation.

questions.text: A 57-year-old nulliparous woman comes to your clinic 2 weeks after noticing a lump in her right breast. Her last mammogram was 4 years ago and was normal. She entered menopause 5 years ago and has been taking hormone replacement therapy for severe hot flashes and vaginal dryness. On examination, you find a firm, nontender mass near the right nipple. There are no skin or nipple changes, and no palpable axillary lymphadenopathy. Abdominal examination is normal. Mammography reveals a noncircumscribed 2-cm mass adjacent to the nipple. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Fine needle aspiration (FNA) cytology cannot provide information about the tissue architecture or receptor status. In patients with a palpable breast lump and suspicious findings on imaging, FNA has been superseded by a more sensitive and more specific modality. The primary role of FNA nowadays is the evaluation of nonsuspicious, cystic lesions in women younger than 30 years of age.

B) CORRECT:

A core needle biopsy is the most appropriate next step in the management of a patient with a palpable breast lump and imaging findings suggestive of breast cancer. This test is used to confirm the diagnosis, evaluate the extent of the tumor, and describe the histology of the tumor and its receptor profile.

Key learning point: Core needle biopsy is the preferred initial diagnostic step for a palpable breast mass with suspicious imaging findings to confirm malignancy and assess tumor characteristics.
Image Description:

DBT: digital breast tomosynthesis

C) INCORRECT:

CA15-3, which is a tumor marker in patients with breast cancer, is used for the follow-up of patients who have already received treatment and not for the diagnosis of breast cancer.

D) INCORRECT:

Excisional biopsy (e.g., via lumpectomy) is an invasive procedure and is therefore not the most appropriate next step in diagnosing breast cancer. It may, however, be used for diagnosis in this patient if the appropriate next step is inconclusive but imaging shows a suspicious lesion or if the appropriate next step cannot be performed (e.g., lack of facilities or expertise for ultrasound-guided procedures).

E) INCORRECT:

Ultrasonography is indicated for all patients with a palpable breast mass and inconclusive mammography. This patient presents with a detectable breast mass on mammography, which requires a different management.
questions.hint: This patient has suspicious findings on mammography and multiple risk factors for breast cancer, including nulliparity, late menopause, and hormone replacement therapy.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman presents for evaluation of a lump she discovered in her left breast one month ago. Her last mammogram was two years ago and was normal. Her maternal aunt had breast cancer at age 68. On examination, a 2-cm firm, non-tender, immobile mass is palpated in the upper outer quadrant of the left breast. Diagnostic mammography reveals a high-density, spiculated mass. A targeted ultrasound confirms an irregular, hypoechoic solid mass corresponding to the palpable finding. The overall assessment is categorized as BI-RADS 5. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the diagnostic evaluation of this patient?

choices.text: Magnetic resonance imaging of the breasts

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While a surgical excisional biopsy provides a definitive diagnosis, the current standard of care is to establish a preoperative diagnosis using a minimally invasive technique. This allows for definitive surgical planning, potentially avoiding a second surgery, and facilitates neoadjuvant therapy if indicated. Excisional biopsy is generally reserved for cases where a needle biopsy is non-diagnostic or discordant with imaging findings.

B) CORRECT:

This patient's clinical and imaging findings are highly suspicious for malignancy (BI-RADS 5), necessitating a tissue diagnosis. An ultrasound-guided core needle biopsy is the standard of care for a palpable, solid mass that is visible on ultrasound. It is a minimally invasive procedure that provides a histologic sample, which is crucial for distinguishing between in-situ and invasive disease and for assessing tumor grade. The tissue obtained is also sufficient for determining hormone receptor (ER/PR) and HER2 status, which are essential for guiding treatment decisions. Ultrasound guidance allows for real-time, accurate targeting of the lesion without the use of ionizing radiation.
Image Description:

DBT: digital breast tomosynthesis

C) INCORRECT:

Fine-needle aspiration is a method for sampling a breast mass, but it provides a cytologic (cellular) sample rather than a histologic (tissue) one. This is a significant limitation, as it cannot reliably differentiate between invasive and in-situ carcinoma and often provides insufficient material for receptor status testing. A different test is required for a definitive diagnosis and treatment planning.

D) INCORRECT:

Breast MRI is a highly sensitive imaging modality, but it is not used to obtain a tissue diagnosis. Its role is typically for screening high-risk patients or for preoperative staging to assess the extent of disease once cancer has already been diagnosed via biopsy. For a well-defined, highly suspicious mass, the immediate next step is to obtain tissue for pathologic confirmation.
questions.hint: This patient has a highly suspicious palpable mass that is visible on ultrasound. The next step is to obtain a histologic diagnosis using the most appropriate image-guidance modality.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presents after discovering a painless lump in her right breast one week ago. She denies nipple discharge or skin changes. Her last screening mammogram 18 months ago was normal. Her medical history is significant for hypertension. A maternal aunt was diagnosed with breast cancer at age 65. On physical examination, a 2-cm, firm, non-tender, immobile mass is palpated in the upper outer quadrant of the right breast. There is no axillary lymphadenopathy or overlying skin dimpling. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial diagnostic study to evaluate this patient's breast mass?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ultrasonography is the recommended initial imaging test for a breast lump in women younger than 30 years of age because it offers higher sensitivity than a mammogram. Young women have higher-density breast tissue, which makes the detection of breast abnormalities in a mammogram more difficult.

B) INCORRECT:

Breast MRI is a highly sensitive test, but it is not the initial imaging modality for evaluating a new palpable mass. Its use is reserved for specific indications, such as screening high-risk patients (e.g., BRCA mutation carriers), determining the extent of known disease, evaluating for implant rupture, or in patients with ambiguous findings in routine imaging tests.

C) INCORRECT:

A core needle biopsy is necessary to obtain a definitive tissue diagnosis of a suspicious breast mass. However, it is not the initial step in the evaluation. Imaging must be performed first to characterize the lesion, assess for other abnormalities in the breasts, and accurately guide the biopsy needle to the target.

D) CORRECT:

Diagnostic mammography is the recommended imaging modality for the evaluation of a palpable breast mass in women ≥ 30 years of age. Along with clinical assessment, it is the initial step in breast cancer diagnosis and helps in deciding whether a biopsy is further required.

Ultrasonography is the initial imaging modality of choice in women < 30 years of age.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presents for evaluation of a right breast lump she found during self-examination two months ago. The lump has not changed in size and is not painful. There is no nipple discharge or skin changes. Her paternal grandmother was diagnosed with breast cancer at age 70. On examination, a 2-cm, non-tender, firm, rubbery, mobile, and well-circumscribed mass is palpated in the upper outer quadrant of the right breast. There is no axillary lymphadenopathy. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial imaging study?

choices.text: Magnetic resonance imaging of the breasts

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Fine-needle aspiration is a biopsy technique used to obtain a cytologic sample from a mass. While it is a component of the diagnostic workup (the 'triple assessment'), it is not the initial step. Imaging is performed first to characterize the mass (e.g., solid versus cystic) and to guide the biopsy if it is deemed necessary.

B) INCORRECT:

Although the clinical features of the mass are suggestive of a benign lesion like a fibroadenoma, any new, persistent, palpable breast mass in a woman with a family history of breast cancer requires a diagnostic workup. Deferring evaluation with imaging is not appropriate, as it is crucial to confirm the benign nature of the mass and rule out the rare possibility of malignancy.

C) INCORRECT:

Breast MRI is a highly sensitive test, but it is not used for the initial evaluation of a palpable mass in a low-risk young woman. Its indications include screening for high-risk patients (e.g., BRCA mutation carriers), assessing the extent of known cancer, or evaluating implant integrity. It is not a first-line diagnostic tool in this clinical scenario due to lower specificity and higher rates of false positives for this indication.

D) INCORRECT:

A diagnostic mammogram is a primary tool for evaluating breast abnormalities in women over 30. However, it is not the initial imaging study of choice for a 24-year-old because the high density of breast tissue in this age group significantly limits its sensitivity. It may be used as an adjunct to another imaging modality if there are suspicious findings, but it is not the most appropriate initial study.

E) CORRECT:

For women younger than 30 with a palpable breast mass and family history of breast cancer, ultrasound is the recommended initial imaging modality. Younger women typically have dense fibroglandular breast tissue, which appears white on a mammogram, potentially obscuring an underlying mass and reducing mammographic sensitivity. Ultrasound is superior in this population for differentiating cystic from solid masses and for characterizing the features of a mass. The clinical findings of a firm, rubbery, mobile, well-circumscribed mass are classic for a fibroadenoma, the most common benign breast tumor in this age group. Ultrasound can further evaluate the mass for benign features, guiding the next steps in management, which may include biopsy or short-term follow-up.
questions.hint: Consider how the patient's age affects the density of her breast tissue and, consequently, which imaging modality will provide the clearest initial evaluation of this palpable mass.

questions.text:
A 46-year-old woman presents after a screening mammogram shows a 1.4-cm spiculated lesion in the upper outer quadrant of her left breast. Her last screening mammogram two years ago was unremarkable. She has no significant past medical history and no contraindications to imaging. The radiologist assigns a BI-RADS category 4 rating. Physical examination reveals no palpable masses or axillary lymphadenopathy. She is anxious for a prompt and accurate diagnosis (see report).
Given her mammographic findings and the classification of this lesion, what is the most appropriate next diagnostic step to obtain a definitive tissue diagnosis?

choices.text: Image-guided core needle biopsy of the suspicious lesion

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Repeat mammography in six months is appropriate for BI-RADS 3 lesions, which are probably benign. A BI-RADS 4 lesion, with spiculated margins and moderate to high suspicion for malignancy, requires a definitive tissue diagnosis rather than observation.

B) CORRECT:

Image-guided core needle biopsy is the preferred diagnostic step for a BI-RADS category 4 breast lesion. This minimally invasive procedure provides sufficient tissue samples while preserving cellular architecture, allowing for accurate histologic evaluation. Imaging techniques, such as ultrasound or stereotactic guidance, ensure precise targeting of the lesion. This method is crucial for differentiating between benign and malignant processes and is emphasized for its high diagnostic accuracy and role in expediting definitive diagnosis, essential for planning appropriate management.

Key learning point: For a BI-RADS IV breast lesion, a needle core biopsy is the preferred method for obtaining a tissue diagnosis due to its ability to provide a larger sample for accurate histological assessment.
Image Description:

DBT: digital breast tomosynthesis

C) INCORRECT:

Fine-needle aspiration (FNA) collects dispersed cellular material without preserving tissue architecture, which is crucial for differentiating histologic types of breast lesions. In a BI-RADS 4 lesion, FNA's limitations, such as higher likelihood of nondiagnostic results and inability to assess stromal invasion, make it unsuitable for definitive diagnosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Excisional surgical biopsy provides a definitive diagnosis but is more invasive, requiring operative intervention and general anesthesia. For a small, easily accessible BI-RADS 4 lesion, minimally invasive, image-guided techniques are preferred due to lower morbidity and quicker recovery.

questions.text: An otherwise healthy 43-year-old woman comes to the physician 2 weeks after she felt a lump in her right breast. The lesion is not painful and has not increased in size since she first noticed it. Her menses occur at regular 28-day intervals; her last menstrual period was 2 weeks ago. Medical history is unremarkable. Her maternal grandmother underwent a modified radical mastectomy for breast cancer at the age of 73 years. She drinks 3 to 4 glasses of wine on weekends and does not smoke cigarettes. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 76/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 126/74 mm Hg. Examination of the breasts show no skin or nipple changes. A firm, nontender 0.5-cm mass is palpated in the outer upper quadrant of the right breast. There is no lymphadenopathy and the remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Mammography shows heterogeneously dense breast tissue; no focal lesion is found. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Reassurance and repeat mammography in 1 year

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In a patient with a clinically palpable breast mass and an indeterminate mammogram, an MRI is indicated only if another imaging modality is also inconclusive. For routine screening, an annual MRI is only performed for women with a high risk of breast cancer (e.g., BRCA mutation carriers or those with genetic syndromes that predispose them to breast cancer, patients with previous chest irradiation, family history of early-onset breast or ovarian cancer), a history of breast augmentation (e.g., breast implantation), and/or previous breast cancer. At this time, the patient does not have any indications for breast cancer screening with MRI.

B) INCORRECT:

In patients ≥ 40 years of age with a palpable breast mass, reassurance and repeat mammography in accordance with the routine screening guidelines (annually according to ACOG and every 2 years according to USPSTF) would be appropriate if the initial mammogram conclusively shows findings of a benign mass. In patients with a palpable breast mass and indeterminate results on mammography, repeating a mammogram in 1 year without characterizing the mass would not be appropriate.

C) INCORRECT:

Because breast density decreases during menses, diagnostic or screening mammography may be delayed until the first week of menses for increased accuracy. In addition, some benign breast lesions (e.g., fibroadenoma) change in size during menses and may be better visualized by mammography during this time. However, if the mammography has been performed for a patient with a clinically palpable breast mass and is inconclusive, a different step should be performed regardless of the timing of the initial mammogram in relation to the menstrual cycle.

D) INCORRECT:

An excisional biopsy of the breast mass (i.e., lumpectomy) is performed to remove a suspected breast malignancy (and a safety margin of healthy tissue, in some cases). An excisional biopsy is only performed if a fine needle aspiration or core needle biopsy is not feasible or if its results are inconclusive. Moreover, a breast tissue biopsy should only be performed after the mass is properly localized and characterized in imaging studies.

E) CORRECT:

Mammography is the first-line imaging modality in patients ≥ 30 years with a palpable breast mass. Ultrasonography is indicated for all patients with indeterminate results on mammography; findings that indicate malignancy include hypoechoic or spiculated masses with ill-defined borders and posterior acoustic shadowing. Patients with such ultrasound findings should undergo a fine needle aspiration or core needle biopsy.

In patients < 30 years of age with a palpable breast mass and findings on clinical assessment that indicate a high probability of malignancy (e.g., positive family history of breast cancer, skin changes, lymphadenopathy, fixation of the mass to the skin or chest wall, nipple retraction, breast asymmetry), ultrasonography is the first-line imaging modality because the relatively high density of breast tissue in this age group often makes mammography inconclusive. A patient < 30 years of age with a palpable breast mass and a low probability of malignancy on clinical assessment should be observed for 1–2 months. If the mass persists, a repeat breast ultrasound should be performed; no further management is necessary if the mass resolves.
Image Description:

DBT: digital breast tomosynthesis
questions.hint: In patients with a palpable breast mass and inconclusive mammography, further workup is required to screen for breast cancer.
